ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a good understanding of how Chinese news is written, with its succinct, formal vocabulary and grammatical structures.  At the same time, the course asked us to read current news in Chinese as a way to learn more about the format, so I ended up reading more news.
I learned how to understand and use many of the most common structures and vocabulary seen in the news in Chinese.
I learned how to use advanced Chinese vocabulary terms to explain current events.
Knowledge of current affairs and chinese terms for current affairs

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Useful readings, vocabulary, grammar, and exercises.  Essay assignments were helpful, and I learned by doing.  Weaknesses: Assignments and details for each class were never set in stone.  Each unit was determined based on a recent news piece, but that meant we didnt know the homework for the next week until Saturday/Sunday.  It was hard to get ahead, and sometimes assignments would change mid-week.  Also the grade cut-off makes no sense - only 96+ would be considered an A.

I think that this course is good in its flexibility and covering chapters in the textbook most relevant to current news. It was a bit too much of a workload at the beginning, but the professors listened to our input to adjust the workload.
Some of the practices are a little repetitive but helps memorization, not much discussion in class, quizlet vocabs might be hard for some

Strengths: diversity of homework assignments
Weaknesses: final project was assigned pretty late, a lot of the course grading was not transparent, very hard to predict the grade you will get at the end

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, Liu Laoshi is the sweetest and you not only learn a lot of Chinese, but also current events.

Yes, I would. Even though it can be unorganized, and you might start off the term thinking it will be the hardest and highest workload class ever, it wont end up being that way!  I learned a lot about how to read and write news, which will help me stay more in touch with Chinese media and my family.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to read and understand the news in Chinese.
They came up with a textbook this year so there is more homework than what other folks have said. Quite a lot of work to be completed weekly but I think the grading was pretty good for my class
